prompt: Facts: Marriage between Anirudhsing Jagmal Singh Jadeja (Accused No. 1 - A1) and Rajvirba (deceased).; Allegations of persistent demands for Rs. 10,000 as dowry and consequent ill-treatment of Rajvirba by A1 and his family members (Accused Nos. 2-4: A2-father-in-law, A3-mother-in-law, A4-brother-in-law).; Rajvirba went to her parental home due to the alleged ill-treatment.; On 13th August 1985, Rajvirba returned to her matrimonial home in village Kotda Nayani, District Rajkot.; On the night between 14th and 15th August 1985, Rajvirba died.; Her body was found hanging from a ceiling fan in a room of the matrimonial house.; Initial report (ADR) suggested suicide.; Complaint filed by Rajvirba's father (PW 5) alleging murder due to non-fulfillment of dowry demands.; Investigation followed, leading to charges against A1, A2, A3, and A4.; Post-mortem report indicated death due to asphyxia as a result of hanging; ligature mark consistent with hanging, no other significant external injuries.; Trial Court acquitted all accused, doubting the evidence regarding dowry demands and finding suicide a plausible cause.; State of Gujarat appealed to the High Court.; High Court upheld the acquittal of A2, A3, and A4.; High Court reversed the acquittal of A1 (husband), convicting him under Section 306 IPC (Abetment of Suicide) and sentencing him to 5 years RI and a fine. Acquittal under Sections 302/34 and 498A IPC was confirmed.; State of Gujarat appealed to the Supreme Court against the acquittal of A1 under S. 302/34 and S. 498A, and the acquittal of A2-A4.; A1 (Anirudhsing) filed a Special Leave Petition (SLP) against his conviction under Section 306 IPC. | IPC: Section 302 (Punishment for Murder), Section 306 (Abetment of Suicide), Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention), Section 107 (Abetment of a thing - Discussed in relation to S. 306)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The High Court erred in acquitting A1 under Section 302/34 IPC; the circumstances indicated homicide disguised as suicide.", "precedents": ["Sharad Birdhichand Sarda v. State of Maharashtra (1984) 4 SCC 116 (Principles of circumstantial evidence)", "State of Punjab v. Iqbal Singh (1991) 3 SCC 1 (Burden of proof in custodial/unnatural deaths)", "Gurbachan Singh v. Satpal Singh (1990) 1 SCC 445 (Presumption when wife dies unnaturally in matrimonial home soon after marriage)"]}, {"argument": "The High Court erred in acquitting A1 under Section 498A IPC; evidence of PW 5, 6, 7 (father, mother, brother) established dowry demands and cruelty.", "precedents": ["Girdhar Shankar Tawade v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 5 SCC 177 (Definition and scope of 'cruelty' under 498A)", "Shanti v. State of Haryana (1991) 1 SCC 371 (Credibility of testimony of parents in dowry cases)", "State of Karnataka v. H.S. Srinivasa (2007) 13 SCC 306 (Harassment linked to unlawful demand sufficient for 498A)"]}, {"argument": "The High Court erred in upholding the acquittal of A2, A3, A4; evidence implicated them in the cruelty and dowry demands.", "precedents": ["Suresh v. State of U.P. (2001) 3 SCC 673 (Principles of common intention under S. 34)", "Paniben v. State of Gujarat (1992) 2 SCC 474 (Family involvement in dowry harassment)", "Kaliyaperumal v. State of Tamil Nadu (2004) 9 SCC 157 (Shared intention can develop on the spot)"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "A1's conviction under Section 306 IPC by the High Court is unsustainable; mere finding of harassment (even if proved, which is denied) does not automatically constitute abetment of suicide.", "precedents": ["Ramesh Kumar v. State of Chhattisgarh (2001) 9 SCC 618 (S. 498A cruelty \u2260 S. 306 abetment; requires positive act of instigation/aiding)", "Sanju @ Sanjay Singh Sengar v. State of M.P. (2002) 5 SCC 371 (Need for direct nexus and mens rea for S. 306)", "Gangula Mohan Reddy v. State of A.P. (2010) 1 SCC 750 (Abetment requires active role/mens rea towards suicide)"]}, {"argument": "The Trial Court's acquittal was based on sound appreciation of evidence and reasonable doubt; the High Court should not have interfered, particularly to convict under S. 306.", "precedents": ["Chandrappa v. State of Karnataka (2007) 4 SCC 415 (Appellate court's limitations in reversing acquittal)", "State of Rajasthan v. Raja Ram (2003) 8 SCC 180 (Acquittal should not be disturbed if view taken by trial court is possible)", "Ajit Singh Thakur Singh v. State of Gujarat (1981) 1 SCC 495 (Presumption of innocence reinforced by acquittal)"]}, {"argument": "Evidence of PW 5, 6, 7 (father, mother, brother) is unreliable, exaggerated, and motivated; their testimony lacks independent corroboration and was rightly disbelieved by the Trial Court.", "precedents": ["State of Haryana v. Ram Singh (2002) 2 SCC 428 (Caution required while evaluating testimony of interested witnesses)", "M. Narsinga Rao v. State of A.P. (2001) 1 SCC 691 (Corroboration desirable for testimony of relatives, though not a strict rule)", "Surinder Kumar v. State of Haryana (2011) 10 SCC 173 (Need for reliable evidence in dowry-related cases)"]}]}
